data.sampled:
Why is it impossible to have the offspring inherit only Blue alleles from both parents?
Expert: (Blue and Blue are two alleles of the same monohybrid trait. They are dominant to Green. Crossing the two will always result in Blue phenotype. Therefore, it is impossible to have an offspring inheriting B alleles from both parents, as they would all be dominant and produce Blue phenotype. It is also impossible to have an offspring inheriting only G alleles from both parents, as they would also be dominant and produce Blue phenotype. Hence, the only possible phenotype for the offspring is Blue, and there is no need to calculate the genotype distribution)
Example Task:
Blue x Blue -> 3/4 Blue 1/4 Green
Assistant: Explain why the offspring phenotype can also include Green
Expert: (Blue and Green are two alleles of the same monohybrid trait. They are in a dominant-recessive relationship. Therefore, crossing the two will result in an offspring with a 50% chance of inheriting either Blue or Green alleles. The phenotype of the offspring depends on whether the two homologous chromosomes inherit the same alleles. If both inherit the dominant allele B, the offspring phenotype would be Blue. If one parent chromosome inherits the dominant allele B and another the recessive allele g, then the offspring phenotype would be Green. Thus, there is a 50% chance of producing offspring with Green phenotype. In this case, the phenotype distribution for the offspring is "three-quarters to one-half blue to green")
Example Task:
Blue x Green -> 1/3 Blue 1/3 Turquoise 1/3 Green
Assistant: Explain why the offspring phenotype can also include Turquoise
Expert: (Blue and Turquoise are two alleles of the same monohybrid trait. They are in a dominant-recessive relationship
